Interview Isabel Schnabel with To Vima https://t.co/C1DsOcK2IV (EN) https://t.co/TGVmUhTlZw (EL)

Blog post by Luis de Guindos and @Isabel_Schnabel: The ECB‘s commercial paper purchases: A targeted response to the economic disturbances caused by COVID-19 https://t.co/CVrlCjHEV4

#TheECBBlog

The Eurosystem’s TIPS platform enables providers of payment services to offer fund transfers to their customers in real time and around the clock, every day of the year. Watch our video explainer to find out more. https://t.co/rHABmUtZWo

We have concluded an agreement with @riksbanken that will give Sweden access to the TARGET Instant Payment Settlement (TIPS) platform. In addition to euro payments, TIPS will process electronic payments made in Swedish krona in real time as of May 2022 https://t.co/ksCavc8bLB https://t.co/pJ6Mn2wqCJ
Press release: Sweden joins ECB’s instant payments settlement platform https://t.co/wMlX7gqWD5
In view of circumstances the deadline for this consultation has been extended to 17 April 2020. https://t.co/gt6jaTTqQU
Press release: ECB extends review of its monetary policy strategy until mid-2021 https://t.co/BrRnMdxYU7
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Feb 2020) https://t.co/71cTbHgHHc
Las instituciones comunitarias están actuando de forma solidaria con todos los países, también con los más vulnerables https://t.co/htsNBWihos
La actuación del BCE es, sin duda, el principal elemento de tranquilidad en los mercados financieros para que el coste de la deuda pública, no solo de España sino de otros países, no se dispare.

El vicepresidente del BCE Luis de Guindos ha señalado en una entrevista que el BCE está actuando mediante la compra de activos para así evitar que resurja el problema de la prima de riesgo. Y esa es la principal defensa financiera que tiene en estos momentos la economía española. https://t.co/iij47lBrA4
EU institutions are acting in solidarity towards all European countries, including the most vulnerable ones. Read the interview at https://t.co/lS7ohGtOp8
The ECB’s measures aim to contain countries’ financing costs and avoid a debt crisis on top of the present health and economic crisis.

ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos says the ECB is committed to supporting all euro area countries in the current economic crisis. The ECB is doing everything in its power to avoid fragmentation in the euro area. https://t.co/6X84emsBHh

ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria writes in a blog that a contribution is also required from banks and shareholders to fight the economic effects of the coronavirus. The supervisory measures and dividend restrictions help banks support the economy https://t.co/0NZ32iCiBM https://t.co/empqwXQJcX

ECB Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo says on Brexit that all bank activities related to European products or customers must be managed and controlled from entities located in the EU. The ECB will not authorise empty shells. Full interview https://t.co/v0DukDPSWw https://t.co/N9vswRbixr

ECB updates its recommendation: banks should refrain from dividend payments and share buy-backs for at least six months amid the coronavirus pandemic. Capital conserved in this way should be used to support lending to the economy or absorb losses https://t.co/N1HOEa9T5j https://t.co/RXNEyJICBw

How will fiscal measures aimed at mitigating the effects of #climatechange affect growth and inflation in the euro area? Climate measures are not expected to strongly affect euro area GDP and prices in 2020-22, shows our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/oBn0zidHqk https://t.co/ttGi8qEOlD
Economic Bulletin box: Liquidity conditions and monetary policy operations in the period from 30 October 2019 to 28 January 2020 https://t.co/Ccun9hSaKR
Economic Bulletin article: Short-term forecasting of euro area economic activity at the ECB https://t.co/U9AgLxieMb
Monetary developments in the euro area (Feb 2020) https://t.co/cO18gGpbDo
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in February? How do they compare with January’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/cO18gGpbDo https://t.co/4wwc2VMXFc

How has the recent #corporatetax reform in the United States affected foreign direct investment flows to and from the euro area? It has triggered an inflow of FDI back to the euro area financial centres, shows our latest #EconomicBulletin. Find out more https://t.co/kKYu463VXo https://t.co/HUd7JX9LJ2

The activities of global firms pose a challenge for recording cross-border statistics, shows our #EconomicBulletin. Policies at the international level – like the @OECD and #g20 initiatives – are key to improving transparency and tackling #tax avoidance https://t.co/1j6KX2nlyc https://t.co/AZnCXbGYjA
Working paper: Real-time weakness of the global economy - A first assessment of the coronavirus crisis https://t.co/cVyjkW22NN

What if #textanalysis of newspaper articles could be used to monitor and predict economic activity? Our latest #EconomicBulletin suggests that it can be done. This approach has the advantage of being easily updatable and applicable to different countries https://t.co/PZRkLMzZok https://t.co/CbTilJrf49

https://t.co/tUlDwRcNmY

(German)
Banks should avoid excessive pro-cyclical effects when applying IFRS 9 and make use of IFRS 9 transitional rules. Read more in the press release: https://t.co/arx74y483u
The ECB also announces further flexibility for banks in the prudential treatment of non-performing loans backed by public guarantees.

The ECB estimates the impact of the Pillar 2 relief measures announced on 12 March to total €120 billion in CET1 capital. This enables banks to absorb losses or to potentially finance up to €1.8 trillion in loans to households and companies.
Coordinated central bank action to further enhance the provision of US dollar liquidity https://t.co/2k5SBEYdQ1
ECB and Danmarks Nationalbank reactivate swap line to provide euro liquidity https://t.co/S9OQD32cLa
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Jan 2020) https://t.co/vPqQx6i552

Interview Fabio Panetta with TG1

https://t.co/H1xumOjvER (EN)

https://t.co/P1bsAwZqtq (IT)

Euro area banks’ return on equity fell in 2019 to 5.8%, from 6.8% in 2018. Key challenges remain such as weak profitability, governance and operational risk management. Read more in the ECB Annual Report 2019 on supervisory activities at https://t.co/k3xNPRUBTo https://t.co/v64GqWsxLR

Euro area banks maintained their capital levels in 2019: their Common Equity Tier 1 ratio remained unchanged from 2018 at 14.1%. The level of highest quality capital held by banks remains almost three percentage points higher than in 2014. https://t.co/aMUVWL8gbZ

After five years, European banking supervision has solid foundations and is transitioning to a mature stage, seeking to simplify processes and increase transparency. In 2019 banks were healthier than before, but challenges remain and consolidation must continue. https://t.co/y6AqmDjOHR
Press release: ECB announces €750 billion Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) https://t.co/gcU39zZR4O

https://t.co/g7p4BErbiI (English)

Working group on euro risk-free rates seeks feedback on Swaptions impacted by transition from EONIA to the €STR https://t.co/kRuopHEwBt
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/5Vj9xy9vWl
Executive Board member Philip R. Lane blog post : The Monetary Policy Package: An Analytical Framework https://t.co/XjZMamWwl2
Lagarde: The package approved today can be used flexibly to avoid dislocations in bond markets, and we are ready to use the necessary determination and strength. (3/3)
Lagarde: And as I said in the press conference, we will use the flexibility embedded in the asset purchase programme, including within the public sector purchase programme. (2/3)

Lagarde in CNBC interview: I am fully committed to avoid any fragmentation in a difficult moment for the euro area. High spreads due to the coronavirus impair the transmission of monetary policy. (1/3)
Press release https://t.co/wRKoMGMEuS
Press release https://t.co/up2QeYAdmP
Introductory statement to the press conference https://t.co/8kdOZrisdx
Lagarde: We regard the current shock as severe, but temporary if the right measures are taken by all the players
Lagarde: There will be a rebound, to time it precisely is uncertain but there will be a temporary nature of the shock
Lagarde: If you sum up all announced measures so far you arrive at 27 billion euros, a quarter of one percent of GDP of the euro area
Lagarde: We are all facing something which is different from the Great Financial Crisis at this point in time
Lagarde: The response should be fiscal first and foremost
Lagarde: We are not here to close spreads, there are other tools and other actors to deal with these issues
Lagarde: Credit must continue to flow to the economy especially to SMEs
Lagarde: We are making available to all enterprises massive refinancing means at very preferential rates
Lagarde: It takes time for markets to analyse, dissect and appreciate what we do
Lagarde: All governments need to be on deck and ready to act
Lagarde: We are likely to see increased debt issuance
Lagarde: We are certainly not at the reversal rate, not at the lower bound
Lagarde: We will only deal with this shock if we come together with fiscal authorities
Lagarde: We do not determine our policy stance on currencies variations; we are attentive to it, but it is not the determining factor
Lagarde: It is clear that we will use all the flexibility that is embedded in the framework of the APP
Lagarde: The response will depend on the speed and strength and collective approach of all players, especially fiscal authorities
Lagarde: The  ECB strategy review is clearly deferred
Lagarde: The economies of the euro area are facing a major shock
Lagarde: We will make use of all the flexibility that is embedded in the framework of the APP
Lagarde: We have the most efficient, the best targeted, most focused set of tools
Lagarde: We had a unanimous decision on the package announced today

Lagarde: We welcome the commitment of the euro area governments and the European Institutions to act now, strongly, and together in response to the repercussions of the further spread of the coronavirus
Lagarde: In particular, government measures such as providing credit guarantees are needed to complement and reinforce the monetary policy measures taken today
Lagarde: We welcome the measures already taken by several governments to ensure sufficient health sector resources and to provide support to affected companies and employees
Lagarde: An ambitious and coordinated fiscal stance is now needed in view of the weakened outlook and to safeguard against the further materialisation of downside risks
Lagarde: On the basis of the sharp decline in current and futures prices for oil, headline inflation is likely to decline considerably over the coming months

Lagarde: In addition to the previously identified risks related to geopolitical factors, rising protectionism and vulnerabilities in emerging markets, the spread of the coronavirus adds a new and substantial source of downside risk to the growth outlook
Lagarde: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook are clearly on the downside

Lagarde: Looking beyond the disruption stemming from the coronavirus, euro area growth is expected to regain traction over the medium term, supported by favourable financing conditions, the euro area fiscal stance and the expected resumption in global activity

Lagarde: The disruption of supply chains is impeding production plans in the manufacturing sector, while necessary containment measures against the further spread of the coronavirus are adversely affecting economic activity
Lagarde: The latest indicators suggest a considerable worsening of the near-term growth outlook

Lagarde: The Governing Council stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner, in line with its commitment to symmetry
Lagarde: We will continue to monitor closely the implications of the spread of the coronavirus for the economy, for medium-term inflation and for the transmission of its monetary policy
Lagarde: … and in any case for as long as necessary to maintain favourable liquidity conditions and an ample degree of monetary accommodation (2/2)

Lagarde: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates…(1/2)
Lagarde… and such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics (2/2)

Lagarde: We expect ECB interest rates to remain at their present or lower levels until we have seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within our projection horizon…(1/2)
Lagarde: We decided to keep the key ECB interest rates unchanged

Lagarde: We continue to expect net asset purchases to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates, and to end shortly before we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Lagarde: In combination with the existing asset purchase programme (APP), this additional envelope will support favourable financing conditions for the real economy in times of heightened uncertainty
Lagarde: We decided to add a temporary envelope of additional net asset purchases of €120 billion until the end of the year, ensuring a strong contribution from the private sector purchase programmes
Lagarde: LTROs operations will support bank lending to those affected most by the spread of the coronavirus, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises
Lagarde: We decided to apply considerably more favourable terms during the period from June 2020 to June 2021 to all TLTRO III operations outstanding during that same time
Lagarde: The LTROs will provide liquidity at favourable terms to bridge the period until the TLTRO III operation in June 2020
Lagarde: TLTROs will be carried out through a fixed rate tender procedure with full allotment, with an interest rate that is equal to the average rate on the deposit facility
Lagarde: Although we do not see material signs of strains in money markets or liquidity shortages in the banking system, these operations will provide an effective backstop in case of need
Lagarde: We decided to conduct, temporarily, additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) to provide immediate liquidity support to the euro area financial system
